briefdescription.para: Polarization in ($\phi$).
Polarization in ($\theta$).
Polarization parameter types.

detaileddescription.para: Generic C++ code should use this function to retrieve the polarization parameters of a truth particle. Since these parameters are optional, the function is designed to tell the user whether the requested parameter could be retrieved or not.

parameterdescription.para: The polarization parameter value read from the object
The polarization parameter that we are interested in

simplesect.para: true if the retrieval was successful, false if it wasn't

detaileddescription.para: Set method for polarization parameter values

In order to keep the symmetry with the getter function, this setter communicates a possible failure in its operation through a return value. Setting a polariozation parameter is much less likely to fail than retrieving one, but in some situations it may still happen...

parameterdescription.para: The polarization parameter value to set on the object
The polarization parameter type that we want to set

simplesect.para: true if the operation was successful, or false if it wasn't

detaileddescription.para: Convenience accessor for a polariozation parameter.

Throws an exception if the request can't be completed. It should mostly be used in PyROOT, as the other form of this function is very hard to use there. But one needs to know for sure that the requested parameter will exist.

parameterdescription.para: The polarion parameter that we are interested in

simplesect.para: The value of the polarization parameter requested

detaileddescription.para: Retrieve a full Polarization with a single call

simplesect.para: May have invalid values -- use valid() to check.
An object holding the full polarization information

xrefdescription.para: Add mappings of e.g. isPrimary, isDecayed, isPrompt, isFromDecay, hasHadronicDecay, hasLeptonicDecay, isHadronic/LeptonicTau ...

briefdescription.para: Definition of the 4-momentum type.
The transverse momentum ($p_T$) of the particle.
The pseudorapidity ($\eta$) of the particle.
The azimuthal angle ($\phi$) of the particle.

detaileddescription.para: Note, not necessarily = $E^2-p^2$ if not on mass shell.

briefdescription.para: The total energy of the particle.
The true rapidity ($y$) of the particle.

detaileddescription.para: Note that m may not be right, though, if not on mass shell. In which case p4().M() will be different from m().

briefdescription.para: The type of the object as a simple enumeration.

description.para: Just convenience methods here, since they all just forward to the utility functions operating on the PDG particle ID code.

briefdescription.para: Physical charge.
3 x the physical charge (so it can be an int for quarks)
Whether the particle is electrically charged.
Whether the particle is electrically neutral.
Whether the particle is a photon.
Whether the particle is a lepton.
Whether the particle is a charged lepton.
Whether the particle is an electron (or positron).
Whether the particle is a muon (or antimuon).
Whether the particle is a tau (or antitau).
Whether the particle is a neutrino (or antineutrino).
Whether the particle is a hadron.
Whether the particle is a meson.
Whether the particle is a baryon.
Whether the particle contains a strange quark (or antiquark).
Whether the particle contains a charm quark (or antiquark).
Whether the particle contains a bottom quark (or antiquark).
Determine if the PID is that of a light flavour (not b or c) meson.
Determine if the PID is that of a light flavour (not b or c) baryon.
Determine if the PID is that of a light flavour (not b or c) hadron.
Determine if the PID is that of a heavy flavour (b or c) meson.
Determine if the PID is that of a heavy flavour (b or c) baryon.
Determine if the PID is that of a heavy flavour (b or c) hadron.
Determine if the PID is that of a b-meson.
Determine if the PID is that of a b-baryon.
Determine if the PID is that of a b-hadron.
Determine if the PID is that of a c-meson.

detaileddescription.para: Specifically, the _heaviest_ quark is a c: a B_c is a b-meson and NOT a c-meson. Charmonia (closed charm) are counted as c-mesons here.

briefdescription.para: Determine if the PID is that of a c-baryon.

detaileddescription.para: Specifically, the _heaviest_ quark is a c: a baryon containing a b & c is a b-baryon and NOT a c-baryon. To test for the simpler case, just use a combination of hasCharm() and isBaryon().

briefdescription.para: Determine if the PID is that of a c-hadron.
Determine if the PID is that of a strange meson.
Determine if the PID is that of a strange baryon.
Determine if the PID is that of a strange hadron.
Check if this particle is a quark.
Check if this particle is a parton.
Check if this particle is a top quark.
Check if this particle is a W boson.
Check if this particle is a Z boson.
Check if this particle is a Higgs boson.
Check if this particle is a resonant state.
Check if this is a generator specific (non-physical) particle.
Cached four momentum.
Flag specifying if the four-momentum is cached.
Default constructor.
Function making sure that the object is ready for persistification.

detaileddescription.para: Class describing a truth particle in the MC record

The xAOD truth record mimicks the structure of HepMC. Truth particles and truth vertices form a decay tree. Where each truth particle is connected to a single production and decay vertex. And each vertex is connected to one or more incoming, and one or more outgoing particles.
